The Model classes¶

class model.Model(mesh, out_dir='./results/', order=1, use_periodic=False, **kwargs)[source]¶

The basic model from which each of these inherit :

  • LatModel - plane strain model
  • D1Model - 1D firn model
  • D2Model - 2D model (SSA, SIA, balance velocity)
  • D3Model - 3D model (first-order, full-Stokes)
Parameters:
  • mesh (Mesh) – the finite-element mesh
  • out_dir (string) – location for the output directory
  • order (int) – order of the shape function basis, default linear
  • use_periodic (bool) – use periodic boundaries or not
L_curve(alphas, control, physics, J, R, adj_kwargs, pre_callback=None, post_callback=None, itr_save_vars=None)[source]¶
RK4(f, y_0, dt)[source]¶

This method is an abstraction of the fourth-order Runge-Kutta method:

The initial value problem is specified as follows:

\[\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} t} = f(t,y), \quad y(t_0) = y_0.\]

Here \(y\) is the unknown function of time \(t\), which we would like to approximate; we are told that \(\dot{y}\), the rate at which \(S\) changes, is a function of \(t\) and \(y\) itself. The function \(f\) and the data \(t_0\), \(S_0\) and step-size \(\Delta t > 0\) must be supplied. The RK4 method specifies the iteration

\[\begin{split}\begin{align} y_{n+1} &= y_n + \tfrac{1}{6} \left(k_1 + 2k_2 + 2k_3 + k_4 \right),\\ t_{n+1} &= t_n + \Delta t \end{align}\end{split}\]

for \(n = 0, 1, 2, 3, \ldots\), using

\[\begin{split}\begin{align} k_1 &= \Delta t \ f\left(t_n, y_n \right), \\ k_2 &= \Delta t \ f\left(t_n + \frac{\Delta t}{2}, y_n + \frac{k_1}{2}\right), \\ k_3 &= \Delta t \ f\left(t_n + \frac{\Delta t}{2}, y_n + \frac{k_2}{2}\right), \\ k_4 &= \Delta t \ f\left(t_n + \Delta t, y_n + k_3\right). \end{align}\end{split}\]

Here \(y_{n+1}\) is the RK4 approximation of \(y(t_{n+1})\), and the next value \(y_{n+1}\) is determined by the present value \(y_n\) plus the weighted average of four increments, where each increment is the product of the size of the interval, \(\Delta t\), and an estimated slope specified by the function \(f\) on the right-hand side of the differential equation.

  • \(k_1\) is the increment based on the slope at the beginning of the interval, using \(y_n\); Euler’s method
  • \(k_2\) is the increment based on the slope at the midpoint of the interval, using \(y_n\) and \(k_1\);
  • \(k_3\) is again the increment based on the slope at the midpoint, but now using \(y_n\) and \(k_2\);
  • \(k_4\) is the increment based on the slope at the end of the interval, using \(y_n\) and \(k_3\).

In averaging the four increments, greater weight is given to the increments at the midpoint. The RK4 method is a fourth-order method, meaning that the local truncation error is \(\mathcal{O}((\Delta t)^5)\), while the total accumulated error is on the order of \(\mathcal{O}((\Delta t)^4)\).

This function returns \(y_{n+1}\) given the parameters :

Parameters:
  • f (function) – function \(\dot{y} = f(t,y)\)
  • y_0 (ndarray) – initial values
  • dt (float) – timestep \(\Delta t\)
Return type:

ndarray
assign_submesh_variable(u_to, u_from)[source]¶

Assign the values from the function u_from to the function u_to, where u_from and u_to are defined over non-identical meshes.

Parameters:
  • u_to – Function or GenericVector to assign to
  • u_from – Function or GenericVector to assign from
assign_variable(u, var, annotate=False, cls=None)[source]¶

Manually assign the values from var to u. The parameter var may be a string pointing to the location of an XDMFFile, HDF5File, or an xml file.

Parameters:
  • u (Function, GenericVector, Constant, float, int) – FEniCS Function assigning to
  • var (float, int, Expression, Constant, GenericVector, string, HDF5File) – value assigning from
  • annotate (bool) – allow Dolfin-Adjoint annotation
assimilate_U_ob(momentum, beta_i, max_iter, tmc_kwargs, uop_kwargs, atol=100.0, rtol=1.0, initialize=True, incomplete=True, post_iter_save_vars=None, post_ini_callback=None, starting_i=1)[source]¶
calc_eta(epsdot)[source]¶

Calculates viscosity \(\eta\), set to self.eta, given by

\[\eta(\theta, \mathbf{u}) = \frac{1}{2}A(\theta)^{-\frac{1}{n}} (\dot{\varepsilon}_e(\mathbf{u}) + \dot{\varepsilon}_0)^{\frac{1-n}{n}},\]

for energy \(\theta\) given by self.theta, flow-rate factor \(A\) given by self.A, strain-rate regularization \(\dot{\varepsilon}_0\) given by self.eps_reg, and Glen’s flow parameter \(n\) given by self.n.

Parameters:epsdot – effective-strain rate \(\dot{\varepsilon}_e(\mathbf{u})\)
calc_normal_vector()[source]¶

Calculates the outward-pointing normal vector as a FEniCS function. This could then be used in any DirichletBC. Saved to self.n_f.

calc_vert_average(u)[source]¶

Calculate the vertical average of the function u.

This method must be overwritten by the class inheriting this class.

Parameters:u – function to be vertically averaged
Return type:the resulting vertical average of u.
calculate_boundaries()[source]¶

Determines the boundaries of the current self.mesh.

External boundaries :

  • self.GAMMA_S_GND – grounded upper surface
  • self.GAMMA_B_GND – grounded lower surface (bedrock)
  • self.GAMMA_S_FLT – shelf upper surface
  • self.GAMMA_B_FLT – shelf lower surface
  • self.GAMMA_L_DVD – basin divides
  • self.GAMMA_L_OVR – terminus over water
  • self.GAMMA_L_UDR – terminus under water
  • self.GAMMA_U_GND – grounded upper surface with \(\mathbf{u}_{ob}\)
  • self.GAMMA_U_FLT – shelf upper surface with \(\mathbf{u}_{ob}\)

Internal boundaries :

  • self.OMEGA_GND – internal cells located over bedrock
  • self.OMEGA_FLT – internal cells located over water

These are then used to define the measures used for integration by FEniCS by calling set_measures().

calculate_courant_number()[source]¶

Calculates and returns the Courant number

\[c = \Delta t \frac{\Vert \underline{u} \Vert}{h}.\]

with ice velocity \(\underline{u}\), cell diameter \(h\), and timestep \(\Delta t\).

color()[source]¶

The color used for printing messages to the screen.

Return type:string
form_energy_dependent_rate_factor()[source]¶

formulates energy-dependent rate factor \(A\), self.A, from

\[A(\theta) = a_T E \left( 1 + 181.5 W_f \right) \exp\left(-\frac{Q_T}{RT'} \right),\]

with energy \(\theta\) defined by self.theta, enhancement factor \(E\) given by self.E, universal gas constant \(R\) given by self.R, empirically-constrained water content \(W_f = \min\{W, 0.01\}\), energy-dependent flow-parameter

\[\begin{split}a_T &= \begin{cases} 3.985 \times 10^{-13} \hspace{3mm} \text{s}^{-1}\text{Pa}^{-3} & T' < 263.15 \\ 1.916 \times 10^{3\hphantom{-1}} \hspace{3mm} \text{s}^{-1}\text{Pa}^{-3} & T' \geq 263.15 \\ \end{cases},\end{split}\]

temperature-dependent creep activation energy

\[\begin{split}Q_T & = \begin{cases} 6.00 \times 10^{4} \hspace{3mm} \text{J mol}^{-1} & T' < 263.15 \\ 1.39 \times 10^{5} \hspace{3mm} \text{J mol}^{-1} & T' \geq 263.15 \\ \end{cases},\end{split}\]

temperature \(T\) given by self.T, and pressure-adjusted temperature \(T'\) given by self.Tp.

generate_constants()[source]¶

Initializes important constants, including :

name of constant value description
self.kcLw 9.2e-9 creep coefficient low
self.kg 1.3e-7 grain growth coefficient
self.Ec 6e4 act. energy for water in ice
self.Eg 42.4e3 act. energy for grain growth
self.etaw 1.787e-3 viscosity of water at Tw
self.eps_reg 1e-15 strain-rate reg. parameter
self.n 3.0 Glen’s flow exponent
self.spy 31556926.0 seconds per year
self.rhoi 910.0 ice density
self.rhow 1000.0 water density
self.rhosw 1028.0 sea-water density
self.rhom 550.0 firn pore-close-off density
self.rhoc 815.0 firn density critical value
self.g 9.80665 gravitational acceleration
self.a0 5.45e10 ice hardness limit
self.Q0 13.9e4 ice activation energy
self.R 8.3144621 universal gas constant
self.ki 2.1 thermal conductivity of ice
self.kw 0.561 thermal conductivity of water
self.ci 2009.0 heat capacity of ice
self.cw 4217.6 Heat capacity of water at Tw
self.L 3.3355e5 latent heat of ice
self.ghf 0.042 * spy geothermal heat flux
self.gamma 9.8e-8 pressure melt. p’t depth dep.
self.nu 3.5e3 moisture diffusivity
self.T_w 273.15 Triple point of water
self.a_T_l 3.985e-13*spy lower bound of flow-rate const.
self.a_T_u 1.916e3*spy upper bound of flow-rate const.
self.Q_T_l 6e4 lower bound of ice act. energy
self.Q_T_u 13.9e4 upper bound of ice act. energy
generate_function_spaces()[source]¶

Generates the finite-element function spaces used by all children of this Model.

The element shape-functions available from this method are :

  • self.Q – \(\mathcal{H}^k(\Omega)\)
  • self.Q2 – \(\mathcal{H}^k(\Omega) \times \mathcal{H}^k(\Omega)\)
  • self.Q3 – \(\mathcal{H}^k(\Omega) \times \mathcal{H}^k(\Omega) \times \mathcal{H}^k(\Omega)\)
  • self.Q4 – \(\mathcal{H}^k(\Omega) \times \mathcal{H}^k(\Omega) \times \mathcal{H}^k(\Omega) \times \mathcal{H}^k(\Omega)\)
  • self.Q_non_periodic – same as self.Q, but without periodic constraints
  • self.Q3_non_periodic – same as self.Q3, but without periodic constraints
  • self.V – same as self.Q3 but formed using VectorFunctionSpace
generate_pbc()[source]¶

return a dolfin.SubDomain of periodic lateral boundaries.

get_norm(U, kind='l2')[source]¶

Calculate and return the norm of and the normalized vector \(\hat{\mathbf{u}}\), of the vector \(\mathbf{u}\) given by parameter U. The parameter kind may be either l2 for the \(L^2\) norm or linf for the \(L^{\infty}\) norm

Parameters:
  • U – GenericVector, list, or tuple of vector components
  • kind – string
Return type:

tuple containing (\(\hat{\mathbf{u}}\), \(\Vert \mathbf{u} \Vert\))
get_xy_velocity_angle(U)[source]¶

Calculates the angle in radians of the horizontal velocity vector \(\mathbf{u}_h = [u\ v]^\intercal\) from the x-axis.

Parameters:U – horizontal velocity vector \(\mathbf{u}_h = [u\ v]^\intercal\)
Return type:Function of angle values.
get_xz_velocity_angle()[source]¶

Parameters:U – vertical velocity vector \(\mathbf{u}_v = [u\ w]^\intercal\)
Return type:Function of angle values.
home_rolled_newton_method(R, U, J, bcs, atol=1e-07, rtol=1e-10, relaxation_param=1.0, max_iter=25, method='mumps', preconditioner='default', cb_ftn=None, bp_Jac=None, bp_R=None)[source]¶

Appy Newton’s method.

Parameters:
  • R – residual of system
  • U – unknown to determine
  • J – Jacobian
  • bcs – set of Dirichlet boundary conditions
  • atol – absolute stopping tolerance
  • rtol – relative stopping tolerance
  • relaxation_param – ratio of down-gradient step to take each iteration.
  • max_iter – maximum number of iterations to perform
  • method – linear solution method
  • preconditioner – preconditioning method to use with Krylov solver
  • cb_ftn – at the end of each iteration, this is called

init_U_mask(U_mask)[source]¶

Set velocity observation mask self.U_mask by calling assign_variable().

This in turn generates a vector of indices corresponding with grounded and shelf vertices:

  • self.Uob_dofs – observations \(\mathbf{u}_{ob}\) present dofs
  • self.Uob_missing_dofs – observations \(\mathbf{u}_{ob}\) missing dofs
Parameters:U_mask – surface-velocity-oberservations mask (1 has observations, 0 does not)

init_beta_SIA(U_mag=None, eps=0.5)[source]¶

Init basal-traction \(\beta\), self.beta, from

\[\beta \Vert \mathbf{u}_B \Vert = \rho g H \Vert \nabla S \Vert,\]

the shallow ice approximation, using the observed surface velocity U_mag as approximate basal velocity,

\[\beta_{\text{SIA}} = \frac{\rho g H \Vert \nabla S \Vert}{\Vert \mathbf{u}_B \Vert + \epsilon}\]
Parameters:
  • U_mag – basal-velocity \(\mathbf{u}_B\) magnitude.
  • eps – minimum velocity \(\epsilon\) introduced to prevent singularity, default is 0.5 m/a.

If U_mag is None, the basal velocity \(\mathbf{u}_B\) is defined from \(\mathbf{u}_{ob}\) as given by self.U_ob. Any gaps in obervation data defined by self.Uob_missing_dofs (see init_U_mask()) are set to values defined by balance-velocity magnitude \(\bar{u}\) as given by self.Ubar.

init_beta_stats(mdl='Ubar', use_temp=False, mode='steady')[source]¶

It’s complicated.

init_uhat(uhat)[source]¶

Set normalized x-component of lateral velocity \(\hat{u}\), self.uhat, by calling assign_variable().

Parameters:uhat – normalized x-component of velocity
init_v(v)[source]¶

Set y-component of velocity \(v\), self.v, by calling assign_variable().

Parameters:v – y-component of velocity
init_v_lat(v_lat)[source]¶

Set y-component of lateral velocity \(v_{g_D}\), self.v_lat, by calling assign_variable().

Parameters:v_lat – y-component of velocity essential condition
init_vbar(vbar)[source]¶

Set vertically averaged y-component of velocity \(\bar{v}\), self.vbar, by calling assign_variable().

Parameters:vbar – vertically-averaged y-component of velocity
init_vhat(vhat)[source]¶

Set normalized y-component of lateral velocity \(\hat{v}\), self.vhat, by calling assign_variable().

Parameters:vhat – normalized y-component of velocity
init_w(w)[source]¶

Set z-component of velocity \(w\), self.w, by calling assign_variable().

Parameters:w – z-component of velocity
init_w_lat(w_lat)[source]¶

Set z-component of lateral velocity \(w_{g_D}\), self.w_lat, by calling assign_variable().

Parameters:w_lat – w-component of velocity essential condition
init_wbar(wbar)[source]¶

Set vertically averaged z-component of velocity \(\bar{w}\), self.wbar, by calling assign_variable().

Parameters:wbar – vertically-averaged z-component of velocity
initialize_variables()[source]¶

Initialize the model variables to default values. The variables defined here are:

Coordinates of various types :

  • self.x – SpatialCoordinate for self.mesh
  • self.h – CellDiameter for self.mesh
  • self.N – FacetNormal for self.mesh
  • self.lat – latitude Function
  • self.lon – longitude Function
  • self.n_f – outward-pointing normal Function

Time step :

  • self.time_step – the time step for transients

Masks :

  • self.mask – shelf mask (1 if grounded, 2 if shelf)
  • self.U_mask – velocity mask (1 if velocity measurements present)

Topography :

  • self.S – atmospheric surface
  • self.B – basal surface

Velocity observations :

  • self.U_ob – observed horizontal velocity vector
  • self.u_ob – \(x\)-compoenent of observed velocity
  • self.v_ob – \(y\)-compoenent of observed velocity

Modeled velocity :

  • self.U_mag – velocity vector magnitude
  • self.U3 – velocity vector
  • self.u – \(x\)-component of velocity vector
  • self.v – \(y\)-component of velocity vector
  • self.w – \(z\)-component of velocity vector

Momentum :

  • self.eta – viscosity
  • self.p – pressure
  • self.beta – basal traction
  • self.E – enhancement factor
  • self.A – flow-rate factor
  • self.u_lat – \(x\)-component velocity lateral b.c.
  • self.v_lat – \(y\)-component velocity lateral b.c.
  • self.w_lat – \(z\)-component velocity lateral b.c.

Energy :

  • self.T – temperature
  • self.Tp – pressure-adjusted temperature
  • self.q_geo – geothermal heat flux
  • self.q_fric – frictional heat flux
  • self.gradT_B – temperature gradient at the bed
  • self.gradTm_B – temperature-melting gradient at the bed
  • self.theta – internal energy
  • self.W – water content
  • self.Wc – maximum allowed water content
  • self.Mb – basal-melt rate
  • self.rhob – bulk density
  • self.T_melt – temperature melting point
  • self.theta_melt– energy melting point
  • self.T_surface – surface temperature b.c.
  • self.alpha – temperate zone marker
  • self.alpha_int – vertically integrated temperate zone marker
  • self.Fb – basal-water discharge
  • self.PE – grid Peclet number
  • self.Wbar – vertical average of water content
  • self.Fb_min – lower bound on self.Fb
  • self.Fb_max – upper bound on self.Fb
  • self.Qbar – vertically-integrated strain heat
  • self.temp_rat – ratio of column that is temperate
  • self.k_0 – non-advective water-flux coefficient

Adjoint :

  • self.control_opt – control parameter for momentum optimization

Balance Velocity :

  • self.adot – accumulation/ablation function
  • self.d_x – \(x\)-component of flow direction
  • self.d_y – \(y\)-component of flow direction
  • self.Ubar – balance velocity magnitude
  • self.uhat – \(x\)-component of normalized flow direction
  • self.vhat – \(y\)-component of normalized flow direction

Stress-balance :

  • self.M_ii – membrane-stress balance \(M_{ii}\)
  • self.M_ij – membrane-stress balance \(M_{ij}\)
  • self.M_iz – membrane-stress balance \(M_{iz}\)
  • self.M_ji – membrane-stress balance \(M_{ji}\)
  • self.M_jj – membrane-stress balance \(M_{jj}\)
  • self.M_jz – membrane-stress balance \(M_{jz}\)
  • self.M_zi – membrane-stress balance \(M_{zi}\)
  • self.M_zj – membrane-stress balance \(M_{zj}\)
  • self.M_zz – membrane-stress balance \(M_{zz}\)
  • self.N_ii – membrane-stress \(N_{ii}\)
  • self.N_ij – membrane-stress \(N_{ij}\)
  • self.N_iz – membrane-stress \(N_{iz}\)
  • self.N_ji – membrane-stress \(N_{ji}\)
  • self.N_jj – membrane-stress \(N_{jj}\)
  • self.N_jz – membrane-stress \(N_{jz}\)
  • self.N_zi – membrane-stress \(N_{zi}\)
  • self.N_zj – membrane-stress \(N_{zj}\)
  • self.N_zz – membrane-stress \(N_{zz}\)
linear_solve_params()[source]¶

Returns a set of linear solver parameters.

nonlinear_solve_params()[source]¶

Returns a set of linear and nonlinear solver parameters.

normalize_vector(U)[source]¶

Create a normalized vector of the vector \(\mathbf{u}\) given by parameter U.

Parameters:U – GenericVector, list, or tuple of vector components
Return type:normalized GenericVector \(\hat{\mathbf{u}}\) of \(\mathbf{u}\)
rotate_tensor(M, R)[source]¶

Rotate the tnesor M by the rotation matrix R.

if M is a rank-two tensor,

\[M_r = R \cdot M \cdot R\]

if M is a rank-one tensor,

\[M_r = R \cdot M\]
Parameters:
  • M – Matrix or Tensor to be rotated
  • R – rotation Matrix or Tensor
Return type:

rotated matrix
save_hdf5(u, f, name=None)[source]¶

Save a Function u to the .h5 file f in the hdf5 subdirectory of self.out_dir. If name = None, this will save the flie under u.name().

Parameters:
  • u (Constant, Function, or GenericVector) – the function to save
  • f (HDF5File) – the file to save to
save_list_to_hdf5(lst, h5File)[source]¶

save a list of functions or coefficients lst to hdf5 file h5File.

Parameters:
  • lst – list
  • h5File (HDF5File) – the file to save to
save_matlab(u, di, filename, val=2.718281828459045)[source]¶

Create Matlab version 4 file output of regular gridded data contained by f. Currently, this function only works for 2D \(x,y\)-plane data.

Parameters:
  • u (Function or GenericVector) – a Function, to be mapped onto the regular grid used by di
  • di – a DataInput object
  • filename (string) – filename to save as
  • val (float) – value to make values outside of mesh, default \(e\)
Return type:

MatLab file <self.out_dir>/matlab/<filename>.mat.
save_mesh(h5File)[source]¶

save the mesh self.mesh to HDF5File h5File.

Parameters:h5File (HDF5File) – the file to save to
save_subdomain_data(h5File)[source]¶

Save the subdomain self.ff, self.ff_acc, and self.cf to hd5f file h5File.

Parameters:h5File (HDF5File) – the file to save to
save_xdmf(u, name, f=None, t=0.0)[source]¶

Save a XDMFFile with name name of the Function u to the xdmf directory specified by self.out_dir.

If f is a XDMFFile object, save to this instead.

If t is a float or an int, mark the file with the timestep t.

Parameters:
  • u (Function or GenericVector) – the function to save
  • name – the name of the .xdmf file to save
  • f (XDMFFile) – the file to save to
  • t (int or float) – the timestep to mark the file with
set_measures()[source]¶

set the new measure space for facets self.ds and cells self.dx for the boundaries marked by FacetFunction self.ff and CellFunction self.cf, respectively.

Also, the number of facets marked by calculate_boundaries() :

  • self.N_OMEGA_GND – number of cells marked self.OMEGA_GND
  • self.N_OMEGA_FLT – number of cells marked self.OMEGA_FLT
  • self.N_GAMMA_S_GND – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_S_GND
  • self.N_GAMMA_B_GND – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_B_GND
  • self.N_GAMMA_S_FLT – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_S_FLT
  • self.N_GAMMA_B_FLT – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_B_FLT
  • self.N_GAMMA_L_DVD – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_L_DVD
  • self.N_GAMMA_L_OVR – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_L_OVR
  • self.N_GAMMA_L_UDR – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_L_UDR
  • self.N_GAMMA_U_GND – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_U_GND
  • self.N_GAMMA_U_FLT – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_U_FLT

The subdomains corresponding to FacetFunction self.ff are :

  • self.dBed_g – grounded bed
  • self.dBed_f – floating bed
  • self.dBed – bed
  • self.dSrf_gu – grounded with U observations
  • self.dSrf_fu – floating with U observations
  • self.dSrf_u – surface with U observations
  • self.dSrf_g – surface of grounded ice
  • self.dSrf_f – surface of floating ice
  • self.dSrf – surface
  • self.dLat_d – lateral divide
  • self.dLat_to – lateral terminus overwater
  • self.dLat_tu – lateral terminus underwater
  • self.dLat_t – lateral terminus
  • self.dLat – lateral

The subdomains corresponding to CellFunction self.cf are :

  • self.dx_g – internal above grounded
  • self.dx_f – internal above floating
set_mesh(f)[source]¶

Sets the mesh instance to f, either a dolfin.Mesh or .h5 file with a mesh saved with name mesh.

set_out_dir(out_dir)[source]¶

Set the output directory to string out_dir.

Parameters:out_dir (string) – the output directory for any output generated by save_hdf5(), save_xdmf(), save_pvd(), save_list_to_hdf5(), save_subdomain_data(), and save_mesh().

Set the facet subdomains FacetFunction self.ff, cell subdomains CellFunction self.cf, and accumulation FacetFunction self.ff_acc from MeshFunctions saved in an .h5 file <f>.

solve_hydrostatic_pressure(annotate=False)[source]¶

Solve for the hydrostatic pressure \(p = f_c = \rho g (S - z)\) to self.p, with surface height \(S\) given by self.S, ice density \(\rho\) given by self.rho, and \(z\)-coordinate given by self.x[2].

Parameters:annotate (bool) – allow Dolfin-Adjoint annotation of this procedure.
thermo_solve(thermo_kwargs)[source]¶

Perform thermo-mechanical coupling between momentum and energy.

This needs be implemented by children of the Model class.

transient_iteration(momentum, mass, time_step, adaptive, annotate)[source]¶

This function defines one interation of the transient solution, and is called by the function transient_solve().

This must be implemented by the child classes for transient_solve() to work.

set_measures()[source]¶

set the new measure space for facets self.ds and cells self.dx for the boundaries marked by FacetFunction self.ff and CellFunction self.cf, respectively.

Also, the number of cells or facets marked by calculate_boundaries() :

  • self.N_OMEGA_GND – number of cells marked self.OMEGA_GND
  • self.N_OMEGA_FLT – number of cells marked self.OMEGA_FLT

  • self.dx_f – internal above floating

set_measures()[source]¶

set the new measure space for facets self.ds and cells self.dx for the boundaries marked by FacetFunction self.ff and CellFunction self.cf, respectively.

Also, the number of facets marked by calculate_boundaries() :

  • self.N_OMEGA_GND – number of cells marked self.OMEGA_GND
  • self.N_OMEGA_FLT – number of cells marked self.OMEGA_FLT
  • self.N_GAMMA_S_GND – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_S_GND
  • self.N_GAMMA_B_GND – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_B_GND
  • self.N_GAMMA_S_FLT – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_S_FLT
  • self.N_GAMMA_B_FLT – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_B_FLT
  • self.N_GAMMA_L_DVD – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_L_DVD
  • self.N_GAMMA_L_OVR – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_L_OVR
  • self.N_GAMMA_L_UDR – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_L_UDR
  • self.N_GAMMA_U_GND – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_U_GND
  • self.N_GAMMA_U_FLT – number of facets marked self.GAMMA_U_FLT

The subdomains corresponding to FacetFunction self.ff are :

  • self.dBed_g – grounded bed
  • self.dBed_f – floating bed
  • self.dBed – bed
  • self.dSrf_gu – grounded with U observations
  • self.dSrf_fu – floating with U observations
  • self.dSrf_u – surface with U observations
  • self.dSrf_g – surface of grounded ice
  • self.dSrf_f – surface of floating ice
  • self.dSrf – surface
  • self.dLat_d – lateral divide
  • self.dLat_to – lateral terminus overwater
  • self.dLat_tu – lateral terminus underwater
  • self.dLat_t – lateral terminus
  • self.dLat – lateral

The subdomains corresponding to CellFunction self.cf are :

  • self.dx_g – internal above grounded
  • self.dx_f – internal above floating

This method will create a dict called self.measures containing all of the ufl.measure.Measure instances for this Model.

set_mesh(mesh)[source]¶

Sets the mesh.

:param mesh : Dolfin mesh to be written

set_srf_mesh(srfmesh)[source]¶

Set the surface boundary mesh.

solve_hydrostatic_pressure(annotate=False, cls=None)[source]¶

Solve for the hydrostatic pressure ‘p’.

thermo_solve(momentum, energy, wop_kwargs, callback=None, atol=100.0, rtol=1.0, max_iter=50, iter_save_vars=None, post_tmc_save_vars=None, starting_i=1)[source]¶

Perform thermo-mechanical coupling between momentum and energy.

Parameters:
  • momentum (Momentum) – momentum instance to couple with energy.
  • energy (Energy) – energy instance to couple with momentum. Currently, the only 3D energy implementation is Enthalpy.
  • wop_kwargs – a dict of arguments for water-optimization method optimize_water_flux()
  • callback – a function that is called back at the end of each iteration
  • atol – absolute stopping tolerance \(a_{tol} \leq r = \Vert \theta_n - \theta_{n-1} \Vert\)
  • rtol – relative stopping tolerance \(r_{tol} \leq \Vert r_n - r_{n-1} \Vert\)
  • max_iter – maximum number of iterations to perform
  • iter_save_vars – python list containing functions to save each iteration
  • starting_i – if you are restarting this process, you may start it at a later iteration.
transient_iteration(momentum, mass, time_step, adaptive, annotate)[source]¶

This function defines one interation of the transient solution, and is called by the function transient_solve().

Currently, the dolfin-adjoint annotate is not supported.

update_mesh()[source]¶

This method will update the surface height self.S and vertices of deformed mesh self.mesh.

vert_extrude(u, d='up', Q='self', annotate=False)[source]¶

This extrudes a function u vertically in the direction d = ‘up’ or ‘down’. It does this by solving a variational problem:

\[\frac{\partial v}{\partial z} = 0 \hspace{10mm} v|_b = u\]
vert_integrate(u, d='up', Q='self', annotate=False)[source]¶

Integrate <u> from the bed to the surface.

generate_stokes_function_spaces(kind='mini')[source]¶

Generates the appropriate finite-element function spaces from parameters specified in the config file for the model.

If <kind> == ‘mini’, use enriched mini elements. If <kind> == ‘th’, use Taylor-Hood elements.
